questions.question: What is the volume of blood in ml, in a child per kg body weight?
questions.explanation: The total blood volume of a child is around 75-80 ml/kg.In the neonatal period, it is 85 ml/kg. It rises to a peak of 105 ml/kg by the end of the first monthand then drops progressively over ensuing months.

questions.question: How do we measure the volume of distribution of body fluid compartments?
questions.explanation: The volume of a fluid compartment in the body can be measured by "indicator (dye)-dilution"method. This method is based on the conservation of mass principle, which means that the totalmass of a substance after dispersion in the fluid compartment will be the same as the total massinjected into the compartment.79Indicator-dilution method formeasuring fluid volumesIndicator Mass A = Volume A x Concentration AIndicator Mass A = Indicator Mass BIndicator Mass B = Volume B x Concentration BVolume B = Indicator Mass B/Concentration BOMARROWFigure shows→If none of the substance leaks out of the compartment, the total mass of substance in thecompartment (Volume B × Concentration B) will equal the total mass of the substance injected(Volume A × Concentration A). By simple rearrangement of the equation, one can calculate theunknown volume of chamber B asVolume B =Volume AxConcentration AConcentration B

questions.question: 500 mg of mannitol was injected out of which 10% is excreted. After equilibrium, plasmaconcentration is 3.2 mg/100 ml. Calculate ECF Volume (L).
questions.explanation: The volume of distribution can be calculated using the formula:80Volume of distributionAmount injected - Amount excretedV =ConcentrationOMARROW• V = volume of compartment• Amount injected = 500 mg•Amount of indicator excreted = 10% of 500 mg = 50mg• Plasma concentration of the indicator = 3.2 mg/100mLCalculation:500mg-50mgV== 14.1L3.2mg/100mlOMARROW2nd method :Mannitol is a substance which leaves blood vessel but can't enter the cell. Therefore, afterattaining equilibrium, conc. of mannitol is same in plasma and interstitial fluidTherefore, by applying dye-dilution technique, mannitol can be used to measure the volume ofECF (x)81Since, 10% is excreted and 10% of 500mg is 50 mg, the amount of mannitol diluted in ECF is 450-mg (500 50) i.e, 450 mg is present in xFrom the given values, 3.2 mg is present in 100 ml, which can be re-written as3.2/100 = 450/xTherefore x = 450 * 100 / 3.2 mLClinical:= 14,062.5 mL= 14 LIV Mannitol is used to treat cerebral oedema (since, it doesn't cross cell membrane, it extractsfluid from brain cells), whereas it is contra-indicated in pulmonary edema (here the fluidcollection is in the interstitial space)

(Since, inulin can cross blood vessel butnot cell wall)Calculation:•Since 10% is excreted, volume of inulin excreted is 1 gm. The amount of inulin diluted in ECF is9 g ( 10 - 1) i.e, 9000mg is present in xFrom the given values, 50 mg is present in 100ml, which can be re-written as50/100 = 9000/xx = 9000 * 100/50= = 9000 * 2= 18,000mL= 18LSecond method :•Since 10% is excreted, volume of inulin excreted is 1 gm.• Amount injected = 10g• Amount excreted = 1gNow, the concentration of inulin after equilibrium is 50 mg/100ml which is equal to 0.05 g/100ml.(Convert the values into same units).82V=Amount injected-Amount excretedconcentrationTherefore, ECF volume = (10-1)*100/0.05 =18000ml = 18 L

questions.question: A dye X which measures the plasma volume is replaced by dye Y which can diffuse out of thecapillaries. Which of the following is true regarding the newly measured plasma volume?
questions.explanation: As the dye diffuses out of the capillaries, the measured concentration of the dye after equilibriumwill be less. So, as per the formula, the volume measured will be falsely high.V = (Amount Injected - Amount Excreted) / Plasma concentration of dyeDetailed explanation:• Dye x measures plasma volume:- dye x doesn't have the property of crossing blood vessel. If thedye x have been used properly, for a normal person then the value would come around 3 L• Dye y crosses capillaries, which means it can cross any blood vessel. This property is used tomeasure the value of ECF. If the dye y is given, for a normal person then the value would comearound 14L•Thus if dye y is given in place of x, then the value would be 14 instead of 3 which is a false andthe obtained value is high when compared to normal value• Therefore the answer is falsely high.83

questions.question: Interstitial fluid volume is best measured using a combination of which two dyes?

questions.question: Which of the following is higher in the ECF compared to ICF?
questions.explanation: The pH of ECF is 7.4 while the pH of ICF is 7.0. There is continuous generation of H+ ions in theICF due to the various metabolic processes. So, the pH of ICF is a little lower compared to ECF.

questions.question: How many grams of NaCl make 1 mole of NaCl?
questions.explanation: 1 mol of NaCl is 58.5 g●• A mole is the gram-molecular weight of a substance (molecular weight of a substance in grams)• In this case, the molecular weight of Na-23 and Cl-35.5.• 1 mol of NaCl = 23 g + 35.5 g = 58.5 gNote•Each mole consists of 6 X 10 23 molecules.•The molecular weight of a substance is the ratio of the mass of 1/12th the mass of an atom ofcarbon-12. Because molecular weight is a ratio, it is dimensionless.•The Dalton (Da) is a unit of mass equal to the mass of 1/12th the mass of an atom of carbon-12.Thus molecular mass is expressed in units.

questions.question: How much is one equivalent of calcium (molecular weight = 40)?
questions.explanation: 1 equivalent of calcium is 20 g.One equivalent is 1 mol of an ionized substance divided by its valency.For calcium in solution, 1 mol is going to be 40g and its valency is 2. Therefore, 1 equivalent ofcalcium is 40/2 = 20g.

questions.question: The unit expressing the concentration of osmotically active particles is
questions.explanation: 85The concentration of osmotically active particles is usually expressed in osmoles. Normal plasmaosmolality is 280 to 290 mosmole/kg H2O• Example• NaCl dissociate into 2 particles- Na+ and Cl- in an ideal solution. Hence we can say that for every1 mole of NaCl, there are 2 osmoles.• If a solute is a non-ionizing compound such as glucose, the osmotic pressure is a function of thenumber of glucose molecules present.• NOTE: The body fluids are not ideal solutions, and although the dissociation of strongelectrolytes is complete, the number of particles free to exert an osmotic effect is reduced owing tothe interaction between the ions. Thus, imol of NaCl per litre body fluids contribute somewhatless than 2 osmoles. The more concentrated the solution, the greater the deviation from the idealsolution.

questions.question: A female patient was infused with a solution which leads to rapid lysis of the RBCs. Whichsolution was most likely infused?
questions.explanation: Urea is a highly permeable solute, 300mMol/L urea solution behaves as a hypotonic solution.Urea diffuses to the inside of RBC's via UTB channels very rapidly, while the rest of the solutes inthe ECF cannot enter the cell. So the ECF now becomes hypotonic. So, fluid enters the RBC andcauses their lysis.Other Options:•Option A: The solution is iso-osmotic. (150mmol of NaCl contains 150mmol of Na+ and150mmol of Cl- ions making the total osmolality 300 mOsm/L.This is equivalent to 0.9% NaClwhich is isotonic.)•Option B and C: The solutions are hyper-osmotic. This will lead to shrinking of the RBCs.Note:• If a cell is placed into a hypotonic solution that has a lower concentration of impermeant solutes(<282 mOsm/L), water will diffuse into the cell, causing it to swell.• If a cell is placed in a hypertonic solution having a higher concentration of impermeant solutes,water will flow out of the cell leading to cell shrinkage.86Effects of hypertonic, isotonicand hypotonic solutions on cell volumeHypertonicIsotonicHypotonicH₂OH₂OH₂OH₂OOMARROW

questions.question: Normal osmolarity of plasma is mainly due to
questions.explanation: Normal plasma osmolarity (~290 mOsm/L) is mainly due to Na+ and its accompanying anions,principally Cl- and HCO3-•Osmolarity (mOsm/L) = 2 [Na+] (mEq/L) + 0.055 [Glucose] (mg/dL) + 0.36 [BUN] (mg/dL)Because sodium and its associated anions (Cl-, HCO3- ) account for about 94 per cent of thesolute in the extracellular compartment, plasma osmolarity (Posm) can be roughly approximatedas• Posm = 2.1 x Plasma sodium concentration• With a plasma sodium concentration of 142 mEq/L, the plasma osmolarity would be estimatedfrom the formula above to be about 298 mOsm/L.•In conditions associated with renal disease, the contribution of two other solutes, glucose andurea, should be included.• Because urea easily permeates most cell membranes, it exerts little effective osmotic pressureunder steady-state conditions. (Ineffective osmoles)• Contribution to plasma osmolarity:• Na+ and associated anions: 270 mOsm/L• Glucose 5 mOsm/L• Urea: 5 mOsm/L• Plasma proteins: 2 mOsm/L• Other ions: 8 mOsm/L87

questions.question: Daily water loss in sweat during normal activities is (ml).
questions.explanation: The amount of water lost by sweating is highly variable, depending on physical activity andenvironmental temperature. The volume of sweat normally is about 100 ml/day, but in veryweather or during heavy exercise fluid loss in sweat occasionally increase to 1 to 2 L/hour.hot

questions.question: Which type of disturbance of body fluids is observed in sweating?
questions.explanation: Sweating loss of water→ Hyperosmotic volume contraction• The osmolarity of ECF increases because sweat is hyposmotic (relatively more water than salt islost).•• ECF volume decreases because of the loss of volume in the sweat.• Water shifts out of ICF; as a result of the shift, ICF osmolarity increases until it is equal to ECFosmolarity, and ICF volume decreases.Plasma protein concentration increases because of the decrease in ECF volume. Althoughhematocrit might also be expected to increase, it remains unchanged because of the water shiftsout of the RBCs, decreasing their volume and offsetting the concentrating effect of the decreasedECF volume.• So, Loss of hypotonic fluid causes hypertonic volume contraction.

questions.question: A 73-year-old diabetic man is brought to the emergency with an altered sensorium. He isdehydrated and his blood glucose is 550mg/dl. A hyperosmolar, hyperglycemic state issuspected. Which of the given formulae can correctly evaluate his serum osmolality?
questions.explanation: 88Calculated serum osmolality = 2 sodium + (glucose/18) + (BUN/2.8).In the given clinical scenario, the patient with untreated type 2 diabetes mellitus has most likelydeveloped a hyperosmolar, hyperglycemic state. His serum osmolality will be significantly raised.The principal determinants of osmolality of serum are the concentrations of sodium, glucose andurea (blood urea nitrogen or BUN).Osmolality is defined as a measure of the osmoles (Osm) of solute per kilogram of solvent(osmol/kg or Osm/kg). The osmolality of the intracellular and extracellular fluids is maintainedbetween 290 and 310 mOsm in each compartment.

questions.question: Various safety factors prevent excessive fluid accumulation in the interstitial spaces. Totalsafety factor against edema is (mmHg)_
questions.explanation: The total safety factor against edema is about 17 mmHg.Summary of safety factors that prevent edema is:• The safety factor caused by low tissue compliance in the negative pressure range is about 3 mmHg⚫ The safety factor caused by increased lymph flow is about 7 mm Hg•The safety factor caused by washdown of proteins from the interstitial spaces is about 7 mm HgTherefore, the total safety factor against edema is about 17 mm Hg.

questions.question: You are an intern and want to determine the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient. Howmuch amount of transient loss/insensible loss per day would you account for in yourcalculations?
questions.explanation: 500-600 ml of transient loss/insensible loss per day would have to be accounted for in thecalculation.Although water is lost through sweating especially in hot climates or during physical exertion, wetend to lose water at rest as well. Physiologically, water evaporates from the skin and lungs at arate of about 600 to 700 ml/day. This is known as insensible water loss.
